content.text: Welcome to the market! In Italy, the outdoor market, 'il mercato', is a great place to buy fresh food. Let's learn how to buy some produce.
At the market, many things are sold 'al chilo', which means 'per kilo'.

data.tip: In Italian, 'ch' is always a hard 'k' sound, never like 'ch' in 'chair'.

content.title: Approaching a Stall
content.setting: You are at a fruit and vegetable stall at an Italian market. The vendor greets you.

conversation_flow.title: Ask how much the tomatoes cost per kilo
Ask for one kilo of tomatoes
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: I pomodori costano tre euro al chilo.

content.text: Great start! Now, what if you see something interesting but don't know what it is? Let's learn how to ask.

data.tip: The 'ggio' sound is similar to the 'j' in 'jam'.

content.title: Trying Something New
content.setting: You're still at the stall, which also sells local cheese. The vendor asks if you want anything else.

conversation_flow.title: Point to the cheese and ask what it is
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Certo. Un chilo di pomodori. Altro?

conversation_flow.title: Ask if you can try a sample
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Questo è pecorino. Un formaggio locale.

conversation_flow.title: Say it's good and you want to buy a piece

content.text: Excellent! You've chosen your items. Now it's time to pay for everything.

data.meaning: How much is it in total?

data.tip: Make sure to pronounce the 'e' at the end. It's not silent like in English.

content.title: Finalizing the Purchase
content.setting: You have your tomatoes and cheese and are ready to pay.

conversation_flow.title: Ask for the total price
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Perfetto! Un pezzo di pecorino. Basta così?

conversation_flow.title: Hand over twenty euros and say it
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Certo. In tutto sono dodici euro.

conversation_flow.title: Thank the vendor and say goodbye
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Grazie. Ecco il resto. Otto euro.
